I had been praying for a truly great old school mobile rpg when i stumbled 
upon DoC in the Play store. On the virtue of its phenomenal reviews (and 
extremely reasonable price), i decided to take a chance and give it a go. I 
will admit that at first I was a bit underwhelmed and stopped playing 
shortly after creating my first custom party. A week or so later I 
revisited it, desperately hoping it could live up to those reviews, and I 
can honestly say that I hate to think how close I came to missing out on 
what turned out to be a true and rare gem, an obvious labor of love and 
grand homage to the days-gone-by of classic rpgs. In the weeks since that 
fateful day, I have spent an embarrassing amount of time exploring, 
looting, and progressing, and have loved every second of it. Thank you 
Volker, for crafting such an enjoyable tale for those of us hungry for a 
taste of yesterday, and for being so accessable to your fans. And to those 
rpgs lovers who have yet to experience DoC, what the hell are you waiting 
for?

content:
As perfect as a game can get inside it's genre. It doesn't shine on the 
story, although it has it's moments, but what it has is incredible tactical 
depth and replayability, more than any other game I have played, and I have 
played hundreds of games over my 35 years of gaming. I have spent over 1500 
hours on this and played it through too numerous times to count (I stopped 
counting at 20:th playthrough), and it is still managing to give 
entertainment to me, even after all this time with it. The game is strongly 
based on replayability (and designed to be replayed) and discovering it's 
nuances, and you will only scratch the surface if you are just going to 
play it through once. The class system is plain incredible with unparalled 
depth and has numerous viable combinations. The classes are NOT designed to 
be balanced, but to be valued in a complete team. The developer has worked 
on the game for an incredibly long time, and still constantly adds new 
things. He is also the friendliest developer around and usually replies 
very quickly to any and all questions on the game's Facebook pages. Maybe 
the most icredible thing about all this is, that developing games is his 
hobby! I would place this game right by Baldur's Gate 2 in quality and 
replayability, and it bypasses all Ultima games by miles. It would easily 
be worth 30‚Ç¨ or more. For me that would be a mere 2 cents per hour, which 
would be a steal! Edited to fix the formatting.

replyContent: You can combat the battery use/heat buildup by reducing the 'cpu usage' slider in the options menu.  In terms of crashes, that is the OS shutting the app down due to memory use.  This can not entirely be avoided on older devices but it helps a lot if you go to page 7 of the options, click 'delete map knowledge', then save, then restart the app.

content: A party-based mobile game which has absolutely no business being as good as it is. A ton of content, constant updates and decent difficulty (from easy to holyshitthatwasabus-hard). It doesn't pretend to be anything else other than a love-letter to crpgs of yesteryear, its pixel graphics matching tried and true fantasy trope (orcs, elves and giant spiders). Locations don't scale to your level; you're free to wander everywhere, dive into any dungeon or dark hole in the mountains. It's really just a question of how well you fare against whatever the landscape throws at you.  There's a ton of loot, skills and gameplay options (autofight AI, turn by turn fight logs, etc.) you can tinker with to better your survivability. There are constant updates and fixes. This is clearly a labor of love and I really do not have it in me to give anything lower than 5 stars.   The only thing it lacks now is cloudsave.

content: So far so good. One thing I really want to show gratitute towards is the classic way the game handles dialogue. I like how it isn't a chore to go around talking to the npcs because you can actually ask questions you want to ask (provided that it's in the lore of the game). A big part of role playing games in my opinion is dialogue options and that's something modern games are missing. There's been so many times in say, skyrim where I get to a new town and all I want to do is ask a gaurd where the closest inn is, or if they know anything about a quest I'm doing.  Why not have a sort of vocabulary system in games where you learn more about the world and get to ask questions about it? - much like a classic rpg. Much like your game.  It's a small detail that I really appreciate.  On top of it being easier to give a reason for the player to explore it also adds the immersion of  'Role playing'. My only complaint thus far is that a lot of the tap gestures can be a little rough on my fat fingers against my tiny phone.  Also the combat can be a little over whelming at first - but that's expected.  It is, after all, a classic rpg. Good job! I'll write an updated review when I get a better chance to play it.
